attachments.displayName:
Good Morning Google+  your daily story about art: 11.03
November 3rd, is believed by some to be the date of the death of Ludovico Carracci, the cousin of the more famous Annibale, and who died in 1619.  Like his more famous cousins Annibale and Augostino, Ludovico was born in Bologna.  Unlike them however, he spent most of his life in Bologna and was rather introverted, slow to speak and given to both piety and introspection.  Along with his background as the son of a butcher, these traits early on gained him the nickname "the Ox".

But the innovations of this "Ox" were to have a very lasting effect on art history, even if he is still in the shadow of his cousins.  As oldest of the three, Ludovico was the driving force in developing the eclectic manner that +R. Harlan Smith points out in the text below. He was also the founder of the "Bologna School", for a while with the support of his cousins and later on alone.  It was this school that taught the new style, diverging from mannerism and paving the way for the Baroque.

One of the driving forces for these changes was the Counter-Reformation.  In an attempt to at least slow if not reverse the popularity of Protestantism, the Catholic Church decided in the Council of Trent in 1563 to dampen not only certain practices, but also what it considered to be excesses in Art.  Cardinal Gabriele Paleotti, a member of the Council, had written a series of texts about the "Sacred and Profane" in art, in which he decried the excesses of mannerism and called for a return to naturalistic styles of clarity and devotion.

Ludovico, as already mentioned was very pious and happy to adopt, further and teach these principles in his style and works.  This painting, the Dream of St. Catherine of Alexandria is one example of a number of his works showing Saints in ecstasy.  We see the sleeping Catherine, to whom the Virgin Mary is appearing in a dream.  Though according to hagiography, this dream must have been an incredible experience, there is none of the drama and excessive emotion that for example Bernini portrayed in his "Ecstasy of St. Theresa", which seems more erotic than religious.  No, Ludovico shows us gentle faces, and only the somewhat hectic folds of Catherine's gowns hint at inner emotional turmoil.

Have a peaceful, gentle Sunday, and tread lightly

Image from WebGallery, here: http://goo.gl/6snMMv 

Additional Information provided by +R. Harlan Smith :

Lodovico Carracci  1555-1619  Italian Early Baroque genre and historical painter.
A man named Johann Joachim Winckelman (1717-1768) was a German art historian who was one of the primary founders of scientific Archaeology. He was the first to arrange the categories of artistic styles on a broad, systematic basis for the history or art. He is regarded, therefore, as the father of the discipline of art history, and it was he who coined the term Eclectic to the Bolognese School of art created by Lodovico Carricci and his cousins Annibale and Agostino from Bologna. The Carravacci were responsible for bringing painting out of the Mannerist style and into the Baroque movement which was regarded then as avant-garde.
The Eclectic school of art was unique in that it was not a style in itself, but rather a mix of the styles of several different elements from the work of other artists to create an entirely new style. The focus was specifically on the Renaissance and Classic periods. What you will see in the work of Lodovico, and his cousins, is the more realistically drawn figure of Michelangelo, a departure from the elongated exaggerations of Mannerism; the brighter palette of Titian, another departure from the grayed palette of Mannerism; Coreggio's chiaroscuro, an element completely absent from Mannerism; and a finer symmetry and grace in the rendering of a painting, also sadly missing from Mannerism. With that you are looking at the nature of Baroque painting by definition.
It may be informative to say that Baroque was a movement because it was in fact a departure from Mannerism, and a style because it was a new method of painting. It was eclectic because of the combination of different elements. You might say it was a new invention using current technology.

#art  #treadlightly  #artandclassontheplus  #EuropeanHistory  #europeanpainting #yourdailyartstory #arthistory
